title: Cat. 89  Fragment of a Bowl, late 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Fragment of a Bowl  
Late 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 5.7 × 3.8 × 1.3 cm (2 1/4 × 1 1/2 × 1/2 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1220

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent bubbly yellow-brown, deep-blue, blue, and opaque white glass. Deep ribbed bowl fragment fabricated by the mosaic glass technique, tooled to create exterior ribs, and polished. Fragment preserves a small segment of vessel wall with four tooled vertical ribs preserved on the exterior. A large cane or band of yellow-brown, sandwiched between thin bands of white with dark blue on either side, was folded and manipulated with segments of transparent blue to form a wavy pattern of reverse squared spiral elements that imitates banded agate or sardonyx.

Broken on all sides; repolished interior face with light-brown weathering crust, some iridescence covers exterior and all edges.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 89 Fragment of a Bowl, late 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.

</section>
